figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Schematic representation of intrinsic (internal) and extrinsic (external) factors and of associated skin-aged phenotype.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Schematic illustration of various mechanisms involved skin aging, in cancer onset and cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) activation.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Representation of relevant overlapping and divergent characteristic of intrinsically aged skin, extrinsically aged skin and of CAFs.

claims.sentence:
Skin Aging Drivers
Aging of the skin is a multifactorial process that involves mechanisms triggered by intrinsic and extrinsic factors that work in concert and influence each other (Figure 1).
Hence, in the skin, UV radiation, the main etiological factor for skin cancer [67], impacts both pre-cancerogenic and resident stromal cells complicating the scenario (Figure 2).

It is interesting to note that a study based on dermal fibroblast cultures of donors <65 years did not find significant age-related differences in bFGF, hepatocyte growth factor HGF, and stem cell factor (SCF) expression suggesting that relevant variations occur late during life [129]
Since the hypersecretion of mitogenic molecules is a peculiar feature of CAFs [130,131,132], the up modulation of growth factors appears to be the turning point for pro-tumorigenic switching of normal fibroblasts (Figure 3).
